span.style: font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: The exterior category deals with constructs formed outside the relationship in the past that are relevant in the present and with constructs outside the relationship that affect it now.

span.style: font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: Such constructs may be growing up with parents and acquiring some of their habits, the job with the boss, the social circle and the raising of children.

span.style: font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: It is important to note that the parenting of children is in this category. This is intentional as the couple relationship may be deeply affected by children but it would be unwise to confuse couple relationships with family relationships. Neither parents of the partners nor children should be allowed to negatively affect or unbalance the couple while there is great benefit of them enriching the couple.

span.style: font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
span.b: Joseph Burgo Phd - Why do I do that?

span.style: font-size: 11px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: Generally speaking we all have sensibilities with their origins usually in our formative years all the way through adolescence or any dramatic event during our lives. We need to understand our own coping mechanisms when faced with negative emotions and endeavor to discuss them with and understand our partners.

span.style: font-size: 11px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;

p.span: Why Do I Do That? adapts the basic strategies of psycho-dynamic psychotherapy to a guided course in self-exploration, highlighting the universal role of defense mechanisms in warding off emotional pain. With easy-to-understand explanations, the first part teaches you about the unconscious mind and the role of psychological defenses in excluding difficult feelings from awareness. Individual chapters in the longer middle section explore the primary defense mechanisms one by one, with exercises to help you identify your own defenses at work. The final part offers guidance for how to "disarm" your defenses and cope more effectively with the unconscious feelings behind them. Psychological defense mechanisms are an inevitable and necessary part of the human experience; but when they become too pervasive or deeply entrenched, they may damage our personal relationships, restrict or distort our emotional lives and prevent us from behaving in ways that promote lasting self-esteem.

span.style: font-size: 11px; font-family: Arial; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;
